metadata.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Respondent (Writ Petition No. 366 of 1969)

facts.text: Appointment of nine trustees to the Kalahastiswara Swami Temple in Kalahasti, Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh.
Andhra Pradesh High Court (Division Bench) quashed the appointment order on the ground that it was not a speaking order, relying on its judgment in Writ Petition No. 2536 of 1967.
Period of office of the appointed trustees expired by the time of Supreme Court hearing.
Respondent contended appeal infructuous due to expiry of trustees' term.
State urged hearing appeal due to considerable importance, as appointments to other institutions held up by High Court judgment.
Supreme Court agreed to hear appeal conditionally on respondent getting costs from State irrespective of result; State had no objection.
Respondent filed suit claiming temple is private family temple or not within Act's definition of temple, or that he is hereditary trustee; suit pending.
Temple is charitable or religious institution included in list under section 6(a) with annual income exceeding rupees two lakhs.
Respondent was one of the persons who applied to be appointed as trustee.

legal_issues.text: Whether in appointing trustees under section 15(1)(a) of the Andhra Pradesh Charitable and Hindu Religious Institutions and Endowments Act, 1966, the Government acts as a quasi-judicial tribunal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appointment of trustees under section 15 is administrative, not quasi-judicial; High Court erred in holding otherwise and requiring speaking order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 15, 16 of the Act; precedents on quasi-judicial vs administrative acts

petitioner_arguments.text: Question of considerable importance as appointments to number of institutions held up.

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal infructuous as trustees' period over.
Contested correctness of K.A. Samajam v. Commr. HRE; section 15 invalid where hereditary trustee exists.

court_reasoning.text: Proceeds on basis respondent applied for trusteeship; section 15 valid per K.A. Samajam; not reconsidering it.
Test for quasi-judicial: (1) lis between parties; (2) objective satisfaction, not subjective; (3) duty to act judicially.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No lis here; respondent had no right to appointment.

court_reasoning.text: Cites Province of Bombay v. K.S. Advani: executive fact-finding not necessarily judicial; duty to act judicially key.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere objective fact determination in executive function not quasi-judicial.

court_reasoning.text: Cites State of Bombay v. Purshottam Jog Naik: real test is duty to act judicially; lis or statute requiring it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even without two parties, if statute requires judicial acting, quasi-judicial.

court_reasoning.text: Cites Shri Radheshyam Khare v. State of MP: tests include lis, evidence, policy vs judicial duty.
Cites Gullapalli Nageswara Rao: duty from statute; lis implies duty.
Act's provisions (ss.15,16) provide guidelines: due regard to denomination, founder wishes; disqualifications in s.16; no weighing merits or speaking order needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretionary administrative act per legislative guidelines.

court_reasoning.text: Revision powers under s.82 do not make s.15 quasi-judicial; no judicial review of Govt orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred implying quasi-judicial functions.

court_reasoning.text: Madras High Court in Commr. HRE v. B.R. Venkatachalapathi took similar view on analogous s.47.

holdings.text: Government appointing trustees under s.15(1)(a) exercises administrative, not quasi-judicial, function; no need for speaking order.

precedents_cited.relevance: Section 15 valid for better administration even with hereditary trustee; due regard to denomination, founder wishes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Province of Bombay v. K.S. Advani
precedents_cited.relevance: Executive fact determination not quasi-judicial unless duty to act judicially.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Purshottam Jog Naik
precedents_cited.relevance: Duty to act judicially distinguishes quasi-judicial from administrative.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Radheshyam Khare v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for duty to act judicially: lis, evidence, policy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corpn.
precedents_cited.relevance: Duty from statute; lis implies judicial duty.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on administrative vs judicial acts.
Appointment of non-hereditary trustees under Madras Act s.47 administrative.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Charitable and Hindu Religious Institutions and Endowments Act, 1966
statutes_cited.relevance: Government appoints trustees for institutions over 2 lakhs income; guidelines on denomination, founder wishes, disqualifications; administrative discretion; revision powers.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1959

outcome.summary: Appeal heard despite mootness on costs condition; Supreme Court held High Court erred, appointment under s.15(1)(a) administrative not quasi-judicial, no speaking order needed; impliedly set aside High Court order.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that government acts administratively; respondent to get costs from State.
outcome.costs: Respondent gets costs from appellant State irrespective of result.

key_quotes.text: the real test which distinguishes a quasi-judicial act from an administrative act is the duty to act judicially.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core test applied to hold no quasi-judicial function.

key_quotes.text: There is...no question of any lis. Nor is there any question of contest between the authority proposing to do the act and the subject opposing it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No lis as no right to appointment.

key_quotes.text: the administrative authority concerned does not have to weigh the relative merits of various candidates in making the appointment of trustees.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No need for speaking order; discretionary per guidelines.
